results.title: Keep moving (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
Promotes the importance of regular exercise including the positive effects of physical exertion and eating the correct foods. Designed to trigger young people’s interest in wanting to include exercise as a regular part of a balanced lifestyle.

results.title: Outside in...Skin (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This program looks at the various things that affect our skin. Topics covered include the structure of the skin, the purpose of the skin and the things that influence the state of our skins such as diet, hygiene, age and sun. This program aims to encourage young people to adopt a healthy, balanced way of living. Rated: G.

results.title: The Rentman
results.creator_credit: Peter Flynn, Ross Hutchens and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A rent collector for the Housing Commission (low cost public housing) calls on one of his tenants, an elderly Aboriginal woman, for their regular cup of tea together. In the past he has protected her against the bureaucracy of the state housing system, but this visit is different.

results.title: Fuelling Up
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Full of Life”.
This program aims to teach young people that diet does not mean the complete denial of nice things to eat, but rather the controlled, planned intake of good quality food - the fuel necessary to power life. Rated: G

results.title: Strange residues
results.creator_credit: Fetus Ferguson, Norman Neeson, Alexander Proyas and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
When a strange batch of unlabelled records start arriving in record shops, customers are drawn irresistably to them. But when played, they cause weird dreams which turn the dreamers into zombies. What are these records? Are they the work of alien beings from another planet, using dreams to manipulate mankind? What is the true story?
A reporter examines this unusual situation.

results.title: Death of a legend
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Wolf is an endangered species in Canada, threatened by man and his technology, largely because of unfounded myths that have grown up around it. This study attempts to disprove the fallacies, showing the wolf’s life cycle, the social organisation of the pack and the wolf’s role in maintaining the balance of nature. (Awards: Toronto; New York; Brussels)

results.title: Death of television
results.creator_credit: Simon White, Mark Lewis and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A man shoots at a woman making a television commercial and finds that a television camera is covering the whole event. Cast features John Derum and Julie McGregor.

results.title: Caravan park
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Anthony Buckley and Phil Noyce
results.brief_description: When their car breaks down on the way to Queensland, a family is forced to take up residence at a caravan park while the father tries to earn enough money to get the car repaired. Much of the film is seen through the eyes of their young son as he comes to realise some of the complexities of his parents’ relationship. Great realist film from the director of ‘Patriot Games’ (1992), ‘The Bone Collector’ (1999) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Based on the story by John Emery. Photography by Tom Cowan, editing by Anthony Buckley and production assistant, Gillian Armstrong. Original Format 16mm/black and white.

results.title: #TeenageDirtbag challenge
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @parishilton's TikTok post
results.brief_description: Over 20 years since Wheatus released their song ‘Teenage Dirtbag’ its nostalgic allure is still as potent as ever. The “Teenage dirtbag” challenge has been popularized by users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Compiling photos from adolescence in the early 2000’ to the Wheatus song. Think emo, myspace, American Pie and of course Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there has been a divide between younger gen z and the millennials who were actually around for the period, dubbed “Indie Sleeze”
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Over 20 years since Wheatus released ‘Teenage Dirtbag’, its nostalgic allure remains as potent as ever. The “Teenage Dirtbag” challenge, which sees people compile photos of their early 2000s adolescence to the song, has been popularised by everyday users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Think emo, MySpace, American Pie and, of course, Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there’s been a divide between younger Gen Z and the Millennials who were actually around for the “Indie Sleeze” period.
description_for_label: Over 20 years since Wheatus released their song ‘Teenage Dirtbag’ its nostalgic allure is still as potent as ever. The “Teenage dirtbag” challenge has been popularised by users and celebrities alike, including Paris Hilton, Christina Aguilera and Tara Reid. Compiling photos from adolescence in the early 2000s to the Wheatus song. Think emo, MySpace, American Pie and of course Paris Hilton. Like most viral trends there has been a divide between younger Gen Z and the Millennials who were actually around for the period dubbed “Indie Sleeze”.
